selected_quotes: @smfleming Jays plan for act on future states (e.g. hunger) What do you think: avian metacognition? #DontNeedChimps
Eurasian jays overcome their current desires to anticipate two distinct future needs and plan for them appropriately
Jays plan for two distinct futures #ifttt
Jay Planning Paper Published in Biology Letters

citation.abstract: Western scrub-jays (Aphelocoma californica) have been shown to overcome present satiety to cache food they will desire in the future. Here, we show that another corvid, the Eurasian jay (Garrulus glandarius), can distinguish between two distinct future desires and plan for each appropriately, despite experiencing a conflicting current motivation. We argue that these data address the criticisms of previous work, and suggest a way in which associative learning processes and future-oriented cognition may combine to allow prospective behaviour.
citation.title: Eurasian jays (Garrulus glandarius) overcome their current desires to anticipate two distinct future needs and plan for them appropriately

news.title: People are animals, too
news.summary: Standfirst: The human brain is special. Just not that special. To understand animal minds, and our own place in the living world, we should remove ourselves from centre stage, argues Peter Aldhous. Free tagging: BrainIntelligenceAnimal rightsCorvidDogWolf

news.title: Clever birds plan for the future
news.summary: Jays store food that they will want in the future, "planning" for their impending needs, say scientists.

news.title: Ravens Are So Smart, One Hacked This Researcher's Experiment
news.summary: We're entering the Dawn of the Planet of the Ravens. In fact, these birds are so intelligent that they're able to plan ahead for future events—something that has only been seen in humans and great apes until now—and will give up an immediately…

wikipedia.title: Eurasian jay
wikipedia.summary: The Eurasian jay (Garrulus glandarius) is a species of bird occurring over a vast region from Western Europe and north-west Africa to the Indian Subcontinent and further to the eastern seaboard of Asia and down into south-east Asia.
